results.title: What happens inside?
results.brief_description: Uses animation and live action to record growth of a fertilised mammal egg. The terms gestation, umbilicus and placenta are explained. Shows birth of a litter of kittens and compares mother’s care of kittens to that of humans. Describes the first four months of human foetal development. From the series “Family living and sex eduation”.

results.title: What Happened to Kerouac?
results.brief_description: This film is a fascinating portrait of Jack Kerouac, the author of “On the road” and reluctant King of the Beat Generation. Includes interviews with family members and cronies including Allen Ginsberg, William Burroughs and Edie Kerouac Parker. This film is a candid and moving biography of one of America’s most influential authors. It is a terrifying and exhilarating film about a troubled genius whose influence is still being felt all over the world.

results.title: What goes into the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit: Merton Park, Frank A. Hoare and John Durst
results.brief_description: The manner in which the raw materials used in a blast furnace - iron ore, coke and limestone - are crushed, blended and otherwise prepared before use in a furnace. Animated diagrams explain the use of a continuous hot air blast.

results.title: What goes around comes around
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Jeremy Ducker
results.brief_description: When Fabian, a reclusive young man who lives and works in a laundrette, meets Lolita, there is only one obstacle to his new found love - his mother who lives upstairs. Gradually he conquers her jealousy and wrath as well as his own insecurities as Lolita teaches him more about himself and his relations with others. Lolita collapses stereotypes and frees him from the suffocating influence of his mother. This is a light hearted and comical film with none the less powerful messages.

results.title: What dreams may come
results.creator_credit: Interscope communications, PolyGram Filmed Entertainment, Metafilmics, Stephen Simon, Barnet Bain and Vincent Ward
results.brief_description: Annie (a painting conservator) and Chris (a paediatrician) barely recover after the tragic loss of their two children when Chris is fatally wounded in a car accident. Shortly afterwards he experiences life on the ‘other side’, aided by Albert (Cuba Gooding Jr), a spiritual guide who steers Chris through the psychological impediments that hinder acceptance of his death. When Annie commits suicide and goes to hell, Chris follows, risking his own eternal presence in heaven, to save her. “What dreams may come” won an Academy Award for its special effects but most critics found the film too preternaturally mawkish and sentimental to be taken seriously as a work that ponders the portentous issues of metaphysics and spirituality. Heaven is depicted as Impressionist paintings come to life; Hell is a vision akin to the horrific Gothic vision of Hieronymus Bosch. But impressive as the film’s aesthetics are, an over-reliance, indeed emphasis, on computer generated wizardry, robs it of any dramaturgical import. Additionally its over-determination to reunite the nuclear family stultifies any dramatic intentions and demands inordinate absurdity from the narrative.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Interscope communications, PolyGram Filmed Entertainment, Metafilmics, Stephen Simon, Barnet Bain and Vincent Ward

results.title: What do you think about getting what you're after
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
This film invites discussion of whether, in business competition, one’s standards of fair play should be lowered. The question revolves around two young women who seek the same job. While one has already applied for the position and is reasonably sure of getting it, she lessens her chances by telling the other that applications are still being accepted. A third woman questions the first’s “softness” and the audience is asked to judge. No. 6 in the series.

results.title: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Philip Howe and Sally Ingleton
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first of May is International Labour Day marking the struggle to achieve the eight hour working day. The Northern Territory is one of the few States still celebrating May 1st as a holiday. This program follows the preparations by community groups, trade unions and artistic directors, Neil Cameron and Jan McDonald, to revitalise the 1989 May Day celebrations in Darwin by creating a lively and colourful parade and festival where workers could have a good time and still prove unity is strength.
